By WARREN GULIN
Four graduate students who
toured China in July presented a
slide show, three seminars and a
movie last Friday for China Day.
The four students, members of
the Committee of Concerned
Asian Scholars, stressed China's
relative introversion and its
dedication to its Marxist
ideology.
The presentation,which began
at 9:30 a.m. in Levering's Great
Hall, illustrated their journey,
focusing on acupuncture in a
hospital, a visit to a model
commune in arid Northwest
China and a four-hour talk with
Premier Chou En-Lai.
At a hospital staffed by
doctors from the People's
Liberation Army on the
outskirts of Sujo, the student
group was amazed as a woman
underwent a gall-stone operation

without any form of chemical
anesthesia. According to the
ancient art of acupuncture,
several long needles were
inserted in the woman to numb
the nervous system and allow
the woman to converse during
surgery. As a scalpel cutthrough
her abdominal wall, she joked
with the students, offering some
of her experiences from the
fields.
Model Commune
After leaving the shrine of
Sun-Yat-Sen, the students took a
long bus ride into the arid region
of Northwest China to the
model commune of Dajai. Set in
a rocky, unproductive region of
China, peasants of the
pre-commune days were forced
to live in caves, the China
scholars said. With the arrival of
the commune however, the
barren land was transformed

into China's most amble section,
they asserted. The modem
methods of land terracing and
irrigation systems quickly
produced a verdant spa complete
with functional housing for the
peasants.

Dajai transformation was Oven
by Mao when in a
communication to other
communes he declared, "In
agriculture, learn from Dajai."

he can, he reportedly returns to
Dajai to toil in the fields among
friends.

Ethical Review Board to Advise Hospital
As a result of the recent
Symposium on the deliberate
starving of mongoloid babies at
the Hopkins Hospital a review
board is being established to
advise the medical staff at the
hospital on questions of medical
ethics.
The panel, consisting of a
pediatrician, a surgeon, a
psychiatrist, a clergyman and a
lawyer, was announced by Dr.
Robert E. Cooke, chief
Pediatrician at the Hospital. He

.stated that the panel would deal
specifically with cases such as
the one involving the mongoloid
infant that was allowed to starve
because its parents refused to
permit surgery for a digestive
defect.
Not Responsible
Cooke expressed hope that
the panel will be a model for
similar review boards in other
hospitals. Members of the group
will be announced within the
next few weeks.

Cooke also announced that
the hospital and the Joseph P.
Kennedy Institute in Baltimore
are compiling lists of persons
willing to be foster parents of
children with special problems
such as mongolism. In the case
with the mongoloid baby,
lawyers decided not to take
action to prevent the baby's
death because no foster parents
could be found and the state
could not take responsibility for
the infant.

After reluctantly letting four mongoloid babies starve to
death during the last few years, the Johns Hopkins
Hospital has decided to set up a review board to advise the
medical staff on ethics. An archaic state law permitted the
parents to retain custody of the unwanted children and let
them refuse doctors the chance to perform surgery for a
digestive defect. A recent symposium on the subject
sharply criticized the doctors and parents, as well as
condemning society for not providing an adequate legal
framework for such cases. The symposium justly
concluded, "Physicians are inadequately educated with
respect to the social and moral implications of decisions
that they are called upon to make." Emerging from all this

Ethics
After reluctantly letting four mongoloid babies starve to
death during the last few years, the Johns Hopkins
Hospital has decided to set up a review board to advise the
medical staff on ethics. An archaic state law permitted the
parents to retain custody of the unwanted children and let
them refuse doctors the chance to perform surgery for a
digestive defect. A recent symposium on the subject
sharply criticized the doctors and parents, as well as
condemning society for not providing an adequate legal
framework for such cases. The symposium justly
concluded, "Physicians are inadequately educated with
respect to the social and moral implications of decisions
that they are called upon to make." Emerging from all this
controversy is the need for clarification of the responsibilities of doctors and for changes in the law.
Basically, it would seem that no doctor or parent or
society should have the right to kill a living human being.
Yet doctors are placed in deep legal trouble if they perform life-saving operations. without consent, and .a valid
point can perhaps be made for families who wish to spare a
defective child a life of misery. Nevertheless, the emphasis
in this controversial area should be on preserving human
life and widening the options available to all those concerned. Furthermore, families would not be so reluctant to
let their babies survive if society provided meaningful
treatment and care for deformed children.
